thread.title: Hawk gets stuck in grille of car in Milford
thread.title_full: Hawk gets stuck in grille of car in Milford - The Boston Globe

title: Hawk gets stuck in grille of car in Milford
text:
Milford Police Department
A hawk was hit by a car in Milford over the weekend.
By Steve Annear Globe Staff February 27, 2017
A red-tailed hawk is in the care of specialists at Tufts Wildlife Clinic after it was hit by a vehicle in Milford over the weekend and got stuck in the front grille of the car.
On Saturday, the large bird of prey flew into oncoming traffic and collided with a Honda that was traveling along Interstate 495, according to Milford Deputy Police Chief Jim Heron.
Advertisement
“It was an unusual circumstance,” Heron said in a telephone interview. “All of a sudden this bird swooped down low. ... The grille was broken and the bird was stuck.”
The female driver pulled off the road and stopped at a nearby gas station to inspect the damage and was shocked to discover the bird lodged in the car’s silver grille, police said in a statement on Facebook Saturday.
Get Fast Forward in your inbox: Forget yesterday's news. Get what you need today in this early-morning email. Sign Up Thank you for signing up! Sign up for more newsletters here Police were called to the scene to help free the hawk, which was later named Hermione, but were unable to remove it from the grille because of its sharp talons and beak. Firefighters arrived soon after. Using a thick blanket and gloves, they removed the trapped hawk.
After the hawk was placed into a container provided by employees at the gas station, it was driven by two bystanders to the Tufts center for evaluation.
In a statement, Dr. Florina Tseng, director of Tufts Wildlife Clinic, said veterinarians found the bird had sustained several serious injuries including head and eye trauma, a wing fracture, and damage to its tail.
Advertisement
“Given the bird’s head trauma, veterinarians will need to wait until the bird is stable to perform additional tests [or] procedures that require anesthesia,” Tseng said.
On Facebook Sunday, police wished the bird well.
“We are hopeful she makes a full recovery and can be returned to her home in Milford soon,” the department wrote.
Steve Annear can be reached at steve.annear@globe.com . Follow him on Twitter @steveannear .
